children.name: a situation in which sb/sth is delayed
delay
children.definition: 1 when sb/sth has to wait, or the length of the waiting time:
examples: Sorry for the delay, Mr Weaver.
delay in
Why was there a delay in warning the public?
delay of
a delay of about an hour
2[U] when something does not happen or start when it should do
without delay
They must restore normal services without delay.
There can be no excuse for anyfurther delay.

children.name: a slight/short delay
examples: There was a slight delay in the departure of the plane.

children.name: a long/lengthy delay
examples: Patients often face long delays in getting the treatment they need.

children.name: a considerable/serious delay
children.definition: very long
examples: After a considerable delay, the report was finally published.

children.name: a 20-minute/6-month/4-week etc delay
examples: A train had broken down, causing a two-hour delay.

children.name: traffic delays
examples: The roadworks are likely to cause serious traffic delays.

children.name: flight delays
examples: Unfortunately flight delays do sometimes occur.

children.name: cause/lead to a delay
examples: The bad weather caused a three-hour delay in sending out rescue helicopters.

children.name: experience delays
examples: People are experiencing considerable delays in receiving their mail.

children.name: face delays
children.definition: be likely to experience them
examples: Commuters face long delays as a result of the rail strikes.

children.name: reduce delays
children.definition: make them shorter and less frequent
examples: The new rules should reduce delays in bringing prisoners to trial.

children.name: a series of delays
children.definition: a number of delays
examples: After a series of delays and setbacks, the project was finally approved.

children.name: hold-up
children.definition: / holdup a delay, especially one caused by an unexpected problem, that interrupts a journey or a piece of work: sự trì hoãn, trì trệ, tắc nghẽn
examples: An accident on the London-Brighton road has caused a major hold-up.
There’s been a hold-up with the builders, so the new office won’t be ready for several months.

children.name: bottleneck
children.definition: a delay in one stage of a process that stops making progress and makes the whole process take longer: sự đình trệ, tắc nghẽn,trì hoãn
examples: ▪ There’s always going to be a bottleneck because only two people review all the applications.
▪ If we don’t hire more people in production we’re going to have a huge bottleneck in a few months.

children.name: delay
children.definition: be ed to make sb/sth late - use this especially about a problem or sth unexpected: bị trì hoãn, bị chậm trễ
examples: Mr Evans has been delayed but will be joining us shortly.
Our plane was delayed by fog.
I mustn’t delay you any longer.

children.name: seriously/badly/slightly etc delayed
examples: The flight was badly delayed because of fog.

children.name: get delayed
examples: There was an accident on the freeway and we got delayed.

children.name: make sb late U
children.definition: make somebody late  to delay someone or something so that they arrive somewhere late:
examples: làm ai đó trễ
make sb late for
làm ai đó trễ
▪ The accident made us late for work.
▪ I’ll let you go - I don’t want to make you late for your appointment.
make somebody late doing something
khiến ai đó trễ để làm gì
▪ Catching a later train made Frank late getting to the office.

children.name: hold up
children.definition: to make sb/sth stop or go more slowly when they are going somewhere: ngăn cản, chặn, giữ lại

children.name: hold sb up
examples: ▪ I won’t hold you up - I can see you’re in a hurry.

children.name: hold up sb/sth
examples: ▪ Get a move on, you two! You’re holding up the whole queue!

children.name: be/get held up
examples: ▪ We got held up in traffic and missed the show.

children.name: keep
children.definition: to delay sb when they are trying to go somewhere: giữ lại
examples: ▪ He should be here by now. What’s keeping him?

children.name: detain
children.definition: to delay sb, especially by keeping them talking or working: ngăn cản, cản trở
examples: ▪ I won’t detain you for much longer, Miss Reid. There are just a few more questions that I need to ask you.

children.name: be unavoidably detainedby sth that you cannot prevent
examples: ▪ Mr Jones should be here, but I’m afraid he’s been unavoidably detained.

children.name: to arrange to do sth at a later time
put off
children.definition: to delay doing sth,especially because there is a problem or because you do not want to do it now.Put offis less formal thandelayorpostpone, and is the usual phrase to use in everyday English: hoãn
examples: I really should go to the dentist, but I keep putting it off.

children.name: put sth off until/till
examples: The concert’s been put off till next week.
The game has been put off till next week.

children.name: put off doing sth
examples: The committee decided to put off making any decision until the new year.
I used to put off making difficult decisions.

children.name: postpone
children.definition: to change the time when sth was planned to happen, and arrange for it to happen laterSYN put back OPP bring forward: :hoãn lại
examples: Several of today’s football games have been postponed because of heavy snow.
postpone doing sth
They’ve decided to postpone having a family for a while.
postpone sth until/till
They decided to postpone the wedding until Pam’s mother was out of the hospital.
The match had to bepostponed untilnext week.
postpone sth for two days/three weeks etc
In 1968, the Oscar ceremony was postponed for two days, following the assassination of Martin Luther King.
postponed indefinitely(= no one knows when it will happen)trì hoãn vô thời hạn
His trial has beenpostponed indefinitely

children.name: delay
children.definition: to not do sth until sth else has happened or until a more suitable time: hoãn lại

children.name: delay something until something
examples: He decided to delay his departure until after he’d seen the Director.

children.name: delay doing something
examples: The police delayed making any announcement until the girl’s relatives had been contacted.

children.name: put back
children.definition: be pushed/moved/put bac if an event is pushed back, sb arranges for it to be held at a later time or date than originally planned: lùi lại

children.name: be pushed/moved/put back to
examples: The meeting has been put back to next Thursday.

children.name: put sth on ice
children.definition: /put sth on the backburner to decide to do or deal with sth at a later time, especially because there is a problem or because you have more important things to deal with immediately.These expressions are rather informal and are often used in business English: tạm gác lại
examples: We’re going to have to put our plans on ice until we can raise some more money.
I’ve put my acting career on the back burner for a while, while I concentrate on my writing.

children.name: procrastinate
children.definition: to delay doing sth that you ought to do, usually because you do not want to do it - used especially to show disapproval: trì hoãn
examples: He hesitated and procrastinated for weeks before he finally told her he wanted their relationship to end.
procrastination [U]
She finally agreed to take the job after months of procrastination.

children.name: procrastinate about/over
examples: Certain players are procrastinating over their contracts in order to see how much money they can squeeze out of their clubs.

children.name: defer
children.definition: to delay doing something until a later date, usually because something else needs to happen first:
examples: She decided to defer her university application for a year so that she could go travelling.

children.name: defer a decision
examples: The committeedeferredtheirdecision.
The decision had been deferred until after a meeting of the directors.

children.name: defer sth until/to
examples: Further discussion on the proposal will be deferred until April.

children.name: to delay to get an advantage
stall
children.definition: to deliberately delay doing sth, or to deliberately stop sb else from doing sth until a later time, either because you are not ready or to give yourself an advantage: trì hoãn
examples: Quit stalling and tell me where she is.
I’m not ready to talk to him yet - go out there and see if you can stall him.
City officials have slowed the development by stalling building permits for the area.

children.name: play for time
children.definition: to deliberately try to delay doing sth or making a decision, because you are not ready or want more time to think about it: câu giờ / kéo dài thời gian
examples: Stop playing for time and give us an answer.
The rebel’s current ceasefire doesn’t amount to much more than playing for time.

children.name: delaying tactics
children.definition: methods used, especially by politicians, in order to delay a plan or decision so that something can be done during the delay: chiến thuật trì hoãn
examples: Some politicians are prepared to use delaying tactics to block the bill.
The peace negotiations were being held up by the delaying tactics of France and Great Britain.

children.name: hold off
children.definition: to delay doing sth, especially while you are waiting for more information or for something else to happen: hoãn lại
examples: House buyers seem to be holding off until interest rates drop.

children.name: hold off doing sth
examples: Let's hold off makinga decision until next week.

children.name: hold off on doing sthUS
examples: They've decided to hold offonbuyinga car until they're both working.

children.name: to make sth happen later or take longer than it should
delay
children.definition: to make sth happen later than it should, or take longer than it should: làm trì hoãn, trì trệ
examples: ▪ The President’s visit had to be delayed because of security problems.
▪ This latest terrorist attack is bound to delay the peace talks even further.

children.name: delay by
examples: ▪ The plane’s departure was delayed by mechanical problems.

children.name: be delayed for 5 hours/2 months etc
examples: ▪ The opening of the new bridge may be delayed for several months.

children.name: hold up
children.definition: to make sth happen late, or make it happen more slowly than it should: làm trì trệ, trì hoãn

children.name: hold up something
examples: ▪ Protesters held up work on the new road.

children.name: hold somebody/something up
examples: ▪ They should have finished that job on Friday - what’s holding them up?
▪ Her stubbornness on this one issue is holding the whole deal up.

children.name: be held up by something
examples: ▪ The peace talks are being held up by continued fighting on the border.

children.name: set back
children.definition: /put backUK  to delay the progress or development of sth by a number of weeks, months etc:

children.name: set sb/sth back
examples: ▪ Your mistake has set us back several weeks.
▪ The Transportation Department first announced that the expressway would be completed by 2002, but it has since set the timetable back.

children.name: set back sb/sth
examples: ▪ The start date kept being put back, for a variety of reasons.

children.name: get bogged down
children.definition: if a person or planned piece of work gets bogged down, they are delayed and prevented from continuing because of complicated or difficult problems: trì hoãn, dừng, “sa lầy”

children.name: get bogged down in
examples: The project got bogged down in a series of legal disputes.

children.name: get bogged down by
examples: Keep the document simple and avoid getting bogged down by complicated formatting.

children.name: on hold
children.definition: If an activity is , it has been intentionally delayed
examples: _Everything's on hold again because of the bad weather.
_The film's beenputon hold until the financial situation improves.
